name: Add and subtract with mixed number fractions 1

skills.name: Add fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator
Add fractions involving mixed number fractions with different denominators
Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator
Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with different denominators

explanations.A: We can do this calculation by adding the whole numbers 2+1 = 3 first. Adding 1/5 and 2/5 is simple as they both have the same denominator, so we can do 1+2 = 3, so we have 3 wholes and 3/5.
explanations.B: This is an improper fraction, what will this be as a mixed number?
explanations.C: This is an improper fraction. We need to give our answer as a mixed number. Also remember that we do not add the denominators.
explanations.D: I think you have added the denominators in your calculation. We only add the numerators.

explanations.A: I think you've just added the numerators, and added the denominators. To start adding the fractions, you first of all need to rewrite the fractions with a common denominator.
explanations.B: This is an improper fraction, what will this be as a mixed number?
explanations.C: Using the method to treat the whole numbers and fractions separately, we can add the wholes to get 3+1=4. Then we need to add the fractions, to do this we need a common denominator, 15 is the best. 2/3 = 10/15, and 1/5 = 3/15. Now we can add the numerators 10 + 3 = 13, and we have an overall answer of 4 wholes and 13/15.
explanations.D: Remember that when adding fractions, we do not add the denominators. We've also been asked for our answer as a mixed number, and this is an improper fraction.

explanations.A: This is an improper fraction, what will this be as a mixed number?
explanations.B: Using the method to treat the whole numbers and fractions separately, we can add the wholes to get 2+2=4. Then we need to add the fractions, to do this we need a common denominator, 20 is the best. 7/10 = 14/20, and 1/4 = 5/20. Now we can add the numerators 14 + 5 = 19, and we have an overall answer of 4 wholes and 19/20.
explanations.C: Remember that when adding fractions, we do not add the denominators. We've also been asked for our answer as a mixed number, and this is an improper fraction.
explanations.D: I think you've just added the numerators, and added the denominators. To start adding the fractions, you first of all need to rewrite the fractions with a common denominator.

explanations.A: We can do this calculation by subtracting the whole numbers 2-1 = 1 first. Subtracting 2/5 from 4/5 is simple as they both have the same denominator, so we can do 4-2 = 2, so we have 1 whole and 2/5.
explanations.B: This is an improper fraction, what will this be as a mixed number?
explanations.C: Don't forget that we don't subtract the denominators too when subtracting fractions. Additionally, this question has asked for the answer as a mixed number, and this is an improper fraction.
explanations.D: Don't forget that we don't subtract the denominators too when subtracting fractions.

explanations.A: This is an improper fraction, what will this be as a mixed number?
explanations.B: Don't forget that we don't subtract the denominators too when subtracting fractions. Additionally, this question has asked for the answer as a mixed number, and this is an improper fraction.
explanations.C: We can do this calculation by subtracting the whole numbers 3-1 = 2 first. Subtracting 2/7 from 5/7 is simple as they both have the same denominator, so we can do 5-2 = 3, so we have 2 wholes and 3/7.
explanations.D: Don't forget that we don't subtract the denominators too when subtracting fractions.

explanations.A: We can do this calculation by subtracting the whole numbers 3-1=2 first. To subtract the fractions, we need a common denominator, 21 is best here. 5/7 = 15/21 and 2/3 = 14/21. 15-14 = 1, so we have 2 wholes and 1/21.
explanations.B: I think you've forgotten to find a common denominator before subtracting. Make sure you also convert your answer back into a mixed number.
explanations.C: Remember we need to rewrite the fractions with a common denominator before we do any calculations. We also do not subtract the denominators when subtracting fractions.
explanations.D: This is an improper fraction, what will this be as a mixed number?

explanations.A: Remember we need to rewrite the fractions with a common denominator before we do any calculations. We also do not subtract the denominators when subtracting fractions.
explanations.B: We can do this calculation by subtracting the whole numbers 5-2=3 first. To subtract the fractions, we need a common denominator, 10 is best here. 3/5 = 6/10 and 1/2 = 5/10. 6-5 = 1, so we have 3 wholes and 1/10.
explanations.C: This is an improper fraction, what will this be as a mixed number?
explanations.D: Remember we need to rewrite the fractions with a common denominator before we do any calculations. We also do not subtract the denominators when subtracting fractions.

explanations.A: Because you split them up and worked on the whole numbers and then the fractions you ended up with a negative fraction. We cannot just turn this into a positive. Start by instead making these into improper fractions
explanations.B: Remember we need to rewrite the fractions with a common denominator before we do any calculations. We also do not subtract the denominators when subtracting fractions.
explanations.C: I would do this question by converting to improper fractions. This becomes 25/7 - 7/4. We can find a common denominator of 28, making it 100/28 - 49/28. 100-49 = 51, so we have 51/28. Converting back into a mixed number, as the question wanted, we get 1 whole and 23/28.
explanations.D: This is an improper fraction, what will this be as a mixed number?

explanations.A: Remember we need to rewrite the fractions with a common denominator before we do any calculations. We also do not subtract the denominators when subtracting fractions.
explanations.B: Because you split them up and worked on the whole numbers and then the fractions you ended up with a negative fraction. We cannot just turn this into a positive. Start by instead making these into improper fractions
explanations.C: I would do this question by converting to improper fractions. This becomes 50/9 - 18/5. We can find a common denominator of 45, making it 250/45 - 162/45. 250-162 = 88, so we have 88/45. Converting back into a mixed number, as the question wanted, we get 1 whole and 43/45.
explanations.D: This is an improper fraction, what will this be as a mixed number?
